posts.name: will
posts.cooked:
We are a couple days away from our competition and our robot no longer drives manually, our autonomous code works but when we enable teleoperator mode and use the joystick it moves for a split second and then stops.

Me and the other programmer are sure we didn’t change the code and we tried older versions of the code that worked before but no longer do. I assumed it has something to do with the wiring as I tried cleaning it up the other day and after cleaning it up we got the errors. I will attach some images of the wiring but I hope someone can look over our code to see if something is wrong with it.

It is the first time me and the one other programmer have ever used the FRC library and we aren’t the strongest in Java so we don’t fully know what’s wrong.

If it helps on the FRC driver station I see this error “internal issue with print and error tags” as well as “ERROR -44019 FRC: The mDNS service is slow to respond check fire wall settings”. and “ERROR 1 DifferentialDrive… Output not updated often enough. See frc docs”

Our GIt

posts.name: khope
posts.cooked:
Just briefly looked at the code.  First thing that seems odd to me is that in your periodic() method of your DriveSubsytem you are calling setDefaultCommand(new DriveCommand()).  I wouldn’t expect to see that there.  I think that should be called once in your RobotContainer class in the constructor.    I’ll keep looking for other things.

Edit: That line of code could be placed in the RobotContainer() constructor method.  Maybe at the end after you call configureButtonBindings() on line 64.  That way it only gets called one time when you RobotConatiner is created during Robot init.   In it’s current location it’s being called every 20ms after your DriveSubsystem is created.

posts.name: John
posts.cooked:
We disconnected the CAN, and the Robot now drives. However we need the CAN connected to Pass inspection. Could you take a look at the wiring, do we need any code for the CAN?

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Paz8OP1EPiR617ZSr5_vsI8nwTFX1GpA/view?usp=share_link

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1jFN6emDTjFHDJ_ELYmnZuJPoTKF6xMHb/view?usp=share_link

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Not related to the problem you’re seeing, but I noticed that your gyroscope is a single-axis gyro and mounted vertically on the robot, measuring the roll. image 1024×768 104 KB

image 1024×768 104 KB

image 1024×768 104 KB

I just wanted to point out that this won’t measure the direction the robot is facing (yaw), it’ll measure how much the robot is tipped side-to-side (roll). You may not even be using it, and I doubt it’s related to the problem you’re seeing, but I wanted you to know nonetheless.

Unfortunately I have no insights to the problem you’re seeing at the moment. It may be a good idea to start from an example to verify if it’s code or something else. If it’s code, I’d expect it to work, and you can begin bringing in your code until it stops working. If it’s something else, I’d expect it to not work and you can zoom in on the wiring or mechanics.

posts.name: khope
posts.cooked:
Are you using pneumatics?  I see a subsystem, but is it actually being used?  We haven’t used pneumatics for a couple years, so I’m not super familiar, but from what it looks like by telling the compressor that it’s connected to a CTRE PCM, I’m assuming that it assumes the CAN ID of the PCM is 0.   Can you confirm using Pheonix Tuner that the CAN ID of the PCM is 0?    When you run Phoenix Tuner do you even see the PCM listed?

Edit: I see now that you are using your pneumatics in your DriveSubsystem.  I don’t understand how you are trying to use them since I’m not familiar with the system.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I think you are exactly right on how to fix OP’s problem. If OP wonders why the errors, it’s because the default command takes a lot of time to create and with it in the loop (where it does not belong) it is bogging down the running of the command, access to the radio and CAN bus to the point of nothing working right.

posts.name: will
posts.cooked:
We want to use pneumatics but after a good week of trying to get it to work we were only able to get the solenoids working so we moved on because we realized we were wasting time. We can try getting rid of the pneumatics subsystem and see if that helps at all.

We do see them PCM and PDP listed when we run Phoenix Tuner and we tried updating their firmware but for some reason our compressor just never gets enabled or turned on. We had another thread a week or so ago and unfortunately we were unable to fix the issue.

posts.name: will
posts.cooked: I will try this during lunch and get back to you, thank you for your help.

posts.name: will
posts.cooked:
Thank you for the heads up, we are currently not using the gyro but it is defiantly something we want to use for our autonomous routine when getting onto the charged up platform.

We are pretty confident that the issue lies with the wiring or mechanics because older versions of the code that use to work don’t work anymore.

Thanks for the help.

posts.name: khope
posts.cooked: If I remember correctly, if things are wired up correctly, the compressor should turn on automatically when you enable your bot if there is a subsystem with an Solenoid or DoubleSolenoid created, which it looks like you have.   We did a simple system this off-season with pneumatics, but I think the only copy of the code is on one of the student’s computers.  I’ll see if I can get a hold of it and share it.   I don’t recall ever having to create a Compressor object.  We just created DoubleSolenoid objects in a subsystem and that seemed to do the trick.

posts.name: will
posts.cooked: I think that is what should happen but unfortunately even when deleting the compressor object and just leaving the double solenoids it still does not work. If you can get the code that would be great.

posts.name: khope
posts.cooked: He said he’d check his computer tonight for it.  I currently don’t have a system here at home to recreate the test
